segments.text: about sorting out the prisoners according to beliefs, et cetera.
Because we didn't know that.
We had no idea that this was taking place.
And we did have one guy, I do remember, an officer who
interviewed various people, you know, about whatever we wanted to talk about.
I was kind of like a psychiatrist.
Now tell me when this took place.
I don't remember which camp.
It was not my last camp.
It was before that.
Because I had about four or five camps.
And I do remember an interview.
That would be interesting if anything.
If that was the program that...
You mentioned where they started to look for the politics in prison.
We didn't think we had any politics because we felt we were just soldiers.
And besides, we felt whatever you believed in, that was okay because that's what you do.
Were you political before you became one of the Army?
No, not really.
Because you were growing up during chaotic times.
Very much.
So my friends, my best friend was.
And they tried to recruit me several times.
But first of all, you had to pay dues.
And they wanted me to join and promise you better jobs and all that kind of stuff.
Kind of like a union, take care of you.
Right.
But I only did, I think I did one tennis clinic.
And I may have done some ski clinics and things like that.
Because I was into sports, into my own personal sports.
Right.
In which I was excelling quite well, because I was champion, Middle Silesia, or Middle Silesian tennis champion.
That's 18 and under.
Yes.
And also, I won a few races in skiing.
And I was entering tournaments.
So I was what you would call a tournament player.
And I was enjoying my skill.
And there weren't that many, so that was my forte, so to speak.
And I didn't want to get into any of these marches and things like that.
I didn't care for that.
I do remember I volunteered once to go way out in some village
kind of to teach some songs, and some of them were English songs.

I don't quite, it doesn't quite, I do remember there was some voluntary work that I did, because I had more education than most of the, at least the villages around the middle of Schlesien, they're all rural people, you know.
But I never got into the mainstream of this Nazi movement.
Like my friend Horst Trispel, which I have a picture of, who rose rapidly in it, became kind of stars.
And then when the army got him, he immediately rose to captain and got into pairs.
Well, you didn't get involved in the political side.
No, for the personal reasons, because I was already involved in my own sports and so forth.
And they would have tennis tournaments that were probably
sponsored by the state, maybe.
That I don't know.
Because they just said, you go to Breslau and there's a tennis tournament.
You're entered and you play.
That's all I know.
So that was my association with the party.
And I did have a lot of problems in my teens, health problems, strangely enough.
I used to tell Jean about it.
I had pneumonia twice.
My poor mother had to nurse me through those things.
Plus diphtheria.
A hard case of diphtheria where I almost died.
And they just came out with this new serum.
And they said, okay, we'll try it out on you.
If he makes it, fine.
If it works, fine.
If not.
And so it worked.
But I was paralyzed in one leg from the serum.
They told me you either break out with some kind of skin disease or you get paralyzed by that serum because it was new.
So that took, you might say, two and a half, three years out of growing up years, out of my teenage years.
I was in quarantine.
My classmates had to throw flowers in my window.
They weren't allowed to see me because it was...

I really was not in the main, I was not that well sometimes, so I would bounce right back and get back into it, but then I had trouble catching up again, which happened to me in school one day after diphtheria.
I just couldn't catch up with the classes.
So I had to make one class over and I had a little more trouble then because they came behind me with French
They already had four years of French and I only had maybe two years of French, you see.
But I had more English.
What caused you to learn English?
That was more or less part of our curriculum.
You either took English or you took French.
The Ober-Rial school in Schweidens.
They had two types of schools that you've probably heard of.
One called the gymnasium, and the ones that became doctors and lawyers, they took Latin there, and they became, it was right next door to us, we shared the same soccer league.
And the ones that could add and had a little feeling for drawings and so on,
They went the other way and became artists or engineers and architects and so on.
And they went to the overall schools and they had different curriculum.
How did you get drawn into the Army?
The war was on.
I was way deferred, part of it.
I was still a student.
And then I think I volunteered for another
type of service, which was working somewhere in East Prussia.
We built drainage in the marshes.
We drained the ditches.
We had no guns or anything.
We had a volunteer company.
And when I came back, in fact, I do remember we were, some of us were supposed to go to the big Nuremberg thing.
But it was canceled because of some invasion.
I don't recall which country was invaded at the time.
Because it did happen so fast, I will probably get, once I sit down and reconstruct it, I can probably figure out which one.
And so when I came back, I was trying to be to Artaud.
And my friend had already been in there a year or so.
Been to Paris.
Oh, so if he had been to Paris, it was after 1940.
Yeah, so it was quite late, you see.
Poland was attacked in 1939.
France fell in the spring of 1940.
So if he had been to Paris, it would have to have been after the summer of 1940.
We'll find that out from the record.
And then I got sick again in the army.
I had another bout with pneumonia.
I had this horrible...
And the coldest place, even colder than my hometown, Olin, I think it was.
Olau.
Olau.
O-H-L-A-U was the name of that town I was stationed in.
And it was one of the artillery units with horses.
The coldest place.
And I come back from exercises one day, and I just killed it.
And I would die in the morning.
So back to the...
several months, and then I got reassigned to another unit.
Your parents are still alive.
There's one sister.
One sister and my brother are still alive.
At that time, yes.
Yes, your sister is Lottie.
And your brother's name was what?
Paul.
Paul.
He'd just gotten married, and he got married, and my sister got married just before I...
But I was... She married Herbert.
Herbert, yeah.

Now, some of my time is probably not quite accurate, because while I was in that artillery with the horses on maneuvers one time, I had this horrible accident where that horse kicked me while I was in the saddle and broke my shinbone.
And it did not heal.
And they were talking about cutting my leg off.
So there I was out again for several months.
And I really didn't think I was going to make 30 at the rate I was going.
I mean, I was bombed with these things all the time.
So I do remember I had that pneumonia and then that accident.
And that seemed to, by then, that was it.
And then I seemed to be all right after that.
And I spent most of my time, for some obscure reason, I spent most of my time as a drill instructor.
Just everybody was coming through, going to various fronts, and I was assigned to drilling.
You know, basic, fundamental, mostly right and left.
Discipline, plain discipline.
Well, that was probably because you were ill and you were being recycled each time as people came through and went on.
You were allowed to heal.
Yeah.
I'm sure I had some because my assignments were really strange because everybody else was going someplace or was being promoted.
You know, nothing happened to me.
I was kind of in a backwater, so to speak.
And finally... We'll find out when the record's coming from Germany, we may see a little notation on the side that says, this man is too important to send to battle.
We need to keep him as a drill instructor here in Natural Leader.
Yeah, and they said I was a good drill instructor because I had a good voice, good presence.
What was your rank at this time?
just over-cannoneer.
That's the strange thing.
I never get promoted.
There was another thing.
But I, the training method, contrary to what most people think, that at least that we used, was a very, was more of role, not reversal, but playing
In other words, just because I might be assigned to take the whole battalion out, you see, and we changed that around.
The guy in command, the two, the officers may never show up.
And then somebody else in charge says, Dennis, you take them all out there and take them up that hill.
Or something, you see.
So you got to take command.
Yes.
And then they'd say, okay, now go back to your rank, whatever that was, you see.
And I never heard people say that so much, you know.
They always think it's very rigid.
It wasn't.
My training was not.
So I was used to taking command of large groups of people.
Right.
without ever having any rank, which is even harder.
Yes, yes.
But they must have listened to you.
Yeah, so you had to have some voice and some presence.
And it was funny, later on, when I was teaching skiing, I could take command of a class in the middle of a blizzard.
And my boss, Bill Klein, used to say, Dennis, tone down your voice.
Everybody can hear you from down below.
Down at the lodge, they could listen to my listen.
My instruction was a thousand feet up.
My voice is so clear.
And that air, too, also in the cold air.
Yeah, in the cold air.
So this was about 1942?
1942, I would say.
And then somehow you went from here to Africa.
Oh, then finally I got an assignment as a K.O.B., Creeks Officer Reverber.
And they said they were going to send me to school in Heidelberg.
And that was the interesting one when I met the fellow that married my girlfriend.
Yes, I remember.
Yes.
was my older lieutenant and instructor.
Oh, was that right?
Yeah.
So you couldn't get too angry after that.
No.
And they really put us to the paces there.
And that very short time was when I was concentrated.
It was more testing and what your aptitudes were rather than teaching.
I didn't teach much, but they wanted to know what you knew.
Like, for instance, that escape thing I told you about, where they just simply tested you and said, now, okay, now we're going to,
You're going to escape from your prisoner and you're going to escape.
They're going to let you free on one downtown Heidelberg and you're going to make your way over there to this corner.
Everything is going to be graded, obviously.
I just took the streetcar.
I thought that was a good way to get there.
The fastest way.
Sure.
Never mind walking in the back side streets and alleys.
So, but as I looked, I could see some officers standing on the street, you know, checking me.
So I ducked behind the seat and the passenger car looked and kind of laughed and smiled, but they didn't.
throw a big commotion on me.
So I got right past those officers.
They let me through, got through, and I got back.
So that was my one and only, and it was not anything they taught me, nothing like a big course, survival course or anything like that.
It was just a test.
Can you, I'll drop you there and can you make it across town without being caught?
Or the soul book.
I think that added to your sense that you could
Yes, exactly.
Exactly, it did.

And another thing gave me courage while I was agonizing over escaping, which took several weeks and hours, and even before the actual break, I never... Oh, now we're in camp, we're at Deming, at Lordsburg.
At Deming, yeah.
But I do remember, in answer to your question, Kenny, I do remember, I was still a student,
And people, strangers were coming into Schweidnitz.
Up to that point, all strangers, we would know everybody in that small town.
And I remember one time, and I still have it in my mind, this little park, and a strange young man walked through.
And I thought to myself, he could be a spy.
We would not know.
And we would not bother him because he didn't do anything to us.
He could just walk through.
But it occurred to me that people could walk
in strange places.
Yes.
And even though other people might be suspicious, but they would probably, if you were lucky, let you get by.
Yes.
If you didn't do anything real dumb.
To call attention to yourself.
Yeah.
That's a good lesson to have learned.
Later on, you know that you could walk through a place.
Yeah, I always thought he looked like a spy.
That's what I thought.
I thought he was going to spy in a little town.
He was even calling attention to himself.
He wasn't causing any harm.
Yeah.
So you found yourself assigned to Heidelberg.
And at the end of this course, there was a
which was Rwanda's course, which I, by the way, was among the first top five graduating.
It must have been about 400 guys.
They immediately came out with a little note on the bulletin board for volunteers for Africa.
And there I agonized again, because I thought for sure they knew by now that I had taught skiing, cross-country skiing to the soldiers, toward Russia.
And I thought for sure they had it already in my file.
But I went in, and that Oberlutend was the only guy, I had to see him, the guy that
Married your sweetie.
Yeah, married my sweetie.

I had to go see him, and I said, I did not, because I came from the eastern part of Europe, and I had read all the books on WWI, what happened to those guys in Russia, and you don't even have to go to war.
Just to be there is a terrible thing.
Just to be there is enough.
Plus those miserable weapons, if you ever...
In sub-zero weather, you touch one of those guns or your hands, you lose half of your skin.
I mean, these things alone.
It's crazy to volunteer for that kind of stuff.
I felt I'd rather my bones can stay in the sun and get dried out by the sun in Africa.
That sounds reasonable.
I would vote for that.
My father fought in the First World War.
The Austrian Army Column College.
the Kaiser-Empire Army, the Austro-Hungarian Army.
He was down in the Italian front, fighting the Italians along the Piave River.
So they accepted you for the African?
Yeah, I was surprised.
They accepted me and shipped me off to Greece.
And there's my little eagle eyes that I picked going over the Brenna Pass.
They only grow in...

above timber and it shows where i was in the hospital as mentioned in there oh yeah these these little inserts are interesting because i tell you what to do how to behave as a prisoner of war and help
Guard your health.
Oh, yes, yes, here on the inside, yes.
Oh, I see.
This is to remember.
The soul book must be kept in, always kept in order.
Everything must be entered.
Your soldier's book is your
No, no, no.
Go ahead.
They took it away from me.
Yeah, I would have thrown it away.
Who did it?
Who did it?
Oh, I see.
Yeah.
How did she have gotten this?
How did she get this?
Well, that's great.
How would they have gotten it?
This had to be carried with you as you were captured from camp to camp.
This was sealed into an envelope, and each commanding officer passed it along to each new commanding officer.
Yes, that's correct.
So somehow, maybe when you left, maybe when you slipped out, they couldn't find you after a certain period of time.
The war was over.
They may have sent this to you.
Yeah, they may have.
That's part of the official papers.
But the most touching part of it is we got all through the book, and now I'm here.
Yes.
I'm taking everything.
Sure, sure.
The Adelweiss.
How do you like that?
Well, usually the unit picture went in here.
The picture of the platoon or the picture of the squad was...
often kept in there.
But this is even nicer.
Doesn't that tell you a good luck that you're telling us?
Yes, it is.
It's kind of a good luck flower.
Yes, it is.
This is how it would be to act as a prisoner.
Wenn du das Unglck hast, when you are unfortunate enough to be taken prisoner,
Well, you had no idea when you got this that you would have the unblick.
But the Germans...

as you well know have this system of hands-on promotion in other words you know in order to become an officer you have to go to the front first you can't just go to school same i was going to be an architect and i had to learn a trade so i became a mason and i in fact i gave that
answer to whoever wrote the book, Mason, as my occupation.
And it was later crossed out that I was a student, because it's confusing, you know, because I really wasn't going to be a Mason.
But you had to be a Mason to even get into the school.
You had to show proof of a trade.
So that's the hands-on type.
How did you go from
How did you get to, you went to Italy, and then from Italy to Greece, and then from Greece to Tunisia?
No, first to Greece.
To Greece.
Yeah.
And Rommel was retreating from Al-Alamin across North Africa faster than we could catch up with him.
That's my impression now.
I'm just trying to find the dates, because the date of transport would be here.
Yeah, that should be in there.
And I was sent to Africa in one of those younger planes.
I have a picture that I might have sent you.
And I got so deathly sick.
And they dropped me off in Crete where they were refueling.
I just simply heaved everything out.
And both hands, I was just awful sick.
By the time I got up,
They decided not to.
I had no more planes going to North Africa or whatever, but they sent me back and I went to Israel to catch up with my unit, which was retreating in North Africa.
So they tried to go around this way, and I got sick and stayed in Crete, but my buddies did get over there.
Because when I caught up with them a week or so
Ten days later, they were already there.
I was right at the tail end of the battle of Tobruk.
Now, these are boys that you went through school with, I see.
Two or three guys that were in the same class.
Have you ever, well, I certainly wouldn't have heard from them since, or you wouldn't have contacted them.
My father did.
No kidding.
He heard from them, because he searched for me.
Yes, I saw the article.
Yeah, and so some of them answered him when they went to school.
And, in fact, one of my nieces sent me a letter also to get in touch with one of the guys that, which I haven't done yet, but I have to get it.
Oh, nice.
That's nice.
So you went to meet your school.
These were school chums.
They were in the same unit.
Mm-hmm.
Something motorized me.
I came right in the middle of a dual artillery barrage when I reported in.
And I remember the first thing you learn is that you dig your own foxhole.
Was that right?
You're not allowed in anybody else's box.
Oh, was that right?
They threw you out?
As soon as the first barrage came in, you try to head for cover, and they throw you out.
You've got to dig your own.
Find out who your friends are.
Yeah, right.
So they were retreating.
You joined the unit about 10 days late.
And you came in the middle of an artillery barrage.
At the end of, near Tobruk.
And from then on it was just one retreat after another.
We were just retreating.
Just stop and then fire and stop and run again and see more foxholes.
I must have dug hundreds of foxholes every night.
New foxhole because the P-38s would come and come over us and shoot like, you know, flying over.
So you had to have cover on.
Yes.
Oh, I see.
Which is hard to explain.
One here.
Which is, is there slight loss?
I forget which side you stand on, but...
It's really terrible.
We didn't have any of these earplugs.
The American soldiers had earplugs, but they carried little plastic things, I'd say.
Invisible sound and smell.
Yes, sure, the acrid acid smell.
And I've never really heard any, I know they make a lot of movies, but I can't quite capture it now.
Is it the sound they can't capture, or the noise, or the smell?
Well, of course the smell they can, but it's the...
when the fragments start, after the thing hits, which is a very scary thing, wherever it hits, nearby or something, everything seems nearby.
Once, after it explodes, you can hear these fragments, you know, you can almost see them, you can, because they make different sounds, you know, these fragments, how they zing all over the place.
That's the scary part because you think, you know,
You have no protection against these things.
You're just standing there practically naked.
At least the old knights had some armor.
I feel sorry.
I mean, the soldiers are just, they feel terrible.
They feel so naked.
Well, Gene says I finally get to tell my war stories.
Yes.
I have never, so you have to kind of pardon me if I get carried away.
Not pardon you at all.
I want to encourage you to think of any story that...
We were in a camp outside.
I saw the Pope.
I got blessed by the Pope.
Oh, my gosh.
Yeah.
At the time, you have to...
I just am not too accurate.
We have to fit it all in.
It's going to fit all in.
Yeah.
The records will give us the time slots.
But...

we i even went to pompeii saw the schmutz the uh the schmutz on the walls the pompeii went to see the pope he blessed my rose and crowns my rosemary yes which i sent back home and then we were camped outside rome i suppose what's naples naples
I mean, there's nothing much or anything waiting for them to get over there for some transfer.
And a lot of it is kind of hazy because you're getting close to the battle zone and you get kind of scared.
Sure.
So you're 22 years old?
About 22, 23.
So it gets pretty scary the closer you get, you know.
And then we just ran most of the time.
Stop, dig another foxhole, shoot off some rounds, run again.
You were firing rifles, or this is still artillery?
No, this is artillery.
They called them storm artillery for some reason.
Because it was a different kind of warfare.
Rommel invented that kind of stuff, that just hit and run kind of thing.
That was his forte.
In fact, he got killed.
a few days after I arrived.
And we were told he was shot by a strafing plane when he actually killed himself.
So he knew what was going on.
We didn't know.
In other words, in general, I forgot.
He did come by one time.
He was a short guy.
Juan Arnim.
Juan Arnim, I think.
A-R-N-I-M.

the day when they i had my orders to go what is that that german academy for the officers there was in berlin it's the same as um yeah but that wasn't no no the regular i can for the life of me instead of west point yes and i had my orders to go there for the final
schooling.
Now, this isn't in North Africa.
It's before North Africa.
After North Africa?
Oh, yeah.
This was my hands-on.
I had my battlefront experience.
And now I got the orders.
And at the same time when the orders came through, they said, you can't go because we're surrounded.
So, it's to stay where you are.
And then we just sat.
They said, stay in your foxholes.
until you get more orders, and we stayed in there for a couple of days.
It seemed like I was reading a book and waiting for something to happen.
I didn't know if anybody was going to come by with machine guns or what, but actually nobody came by.
They kept the command intact almost, and our officers took us in.
And then they were separated into officer camps and so forth.
And we were separated into non-commissioned officer camps and so on.
But the captors didn't come in with machine guns.
But you don't know.
So you were trapped in an area after a long series of retreats.
You got your orders to...

go to Berlin to the officers academy found out that there was no place to go because you couldn't leave because everybody was trapped so the and your officers simply said this stay and sit tight and someone's going to either come and get us or we're going to get out of it or something's going to happen but we're going to sit tight do anything okay your your rank at the time was what um my rank was I think uh
I was made under-officer right about that time, actually.
I was promoted.
Yeah, I was just promoted then for my trip back.
They made me under-officer.
Second lieutenant.
No, it was a sergeant.
Sergeant.
I don't know.

no well it's higher than a third of the german army which was uh private's importance so you found yourself uh waiting sitting around for a couple of days reading a book uh concerned that the next people you would see would be either british or americans or did you know which ones which one
But you knew that you were trapped.
Because the British used a lot of foreign troops.
They used Indian troops.
That's right.
They had the Khyber riflemen coming in.
Yes.
But you knew that you were trapped, and you knew that the next thing...
They were surrounded.
They were surrounded, so it was going to be a surrender.
No mercy.
Right.
Did you have any close hand-to-hand combat?
No.
This is all...
I think I mentioned that episode in the letter, because we wouldn't even know what to do in close combat.
We had no weapons for close combat.
That's right, no pistols, sure.
We had no handguns.
Never issued, in fact, nobody in the German Army has.
I know we didn't have any.
And we only had these great big guns, so what do you do?
They were only good for 10 kilometers or something like that.
They were hauled by motorized units.
There was one in the more modern armies.
So the first people you saw when you were sitting in the foxhole reading
were American soldiers or British soldiers?
No, no foreign soldiers.
Nobody?
Nobody, no.
Your officers?
They just said, get out of your foxhole and follow these guys.
So they, whoever made the sign that surrendered, you know, said we were bringing our own troops and returning them to whoever won.
There was a lot that took them in on this.
It took a lot to cross their lines.
So we just marched in single file and pretty soon one of our guys came out and the British took us away.
We were in some camps and some oasis.
And it was, not much was happening.
And they moved us every so often, it seemed like, in the east.
until you were taken over by the Americans.
So you were actually guarded by British troops.
The line is getting larger and larger as more troops are being brought in from different battles in different areas.
And then you're being funneled in a way farther and farther east toward the larger camps under the hands of the British holding camp.
Well, Steve, I always throw off the direction that you're going, so I can take where it is.
You're remembering a lot of things now, and some of the times you've said it's hard to remember.
Details.
I'm curious, since revealing this to Jim, have you begun to have a lot more memories of things coming back to you, or were these as well-retained all the time?
Was it something you could dwell on all the time, so it stayed in your mind?

I may have on some aspects like when I was you know I was alone a lot for the first few years you know in small rooms I may have dwelled on it but once I got out and made new friends which was great because then I didn't have to think about it and once I had some social contacts and especially once I got married it was even
In fact, Gene always quotes me.
It's one of my, when I said, marriage is so time consuming.
You have no time to think, which is great, you think.
Keeps you, keeps the memories at bay.
Yeah.
So it was very therapeutic to see all these new images and new experiences were coming in, you know, children and so on.
But before that, of course, I had also my social life was not
too bad, I had a lot of good friends, male friends.
This guy that gave me the first job, real decent job, as an estimator salesman, I had somehow found the university courts at Berkeley.
And there were a lot of foreign students there at the time, so my accent didn't show up very much, so I felt comfortable.
Whatever story, cover story I had would probably hold.
And I made some real good friends.
One of them was a Turk.
And he kind of became my mentor because he knew more and he had gone to school for a while and had a very good job, a fabulous job with MasterCard, with the founder of MasterCard.
If you can believe that.
So he had lots of money.
And he was a very generous guy.
And a lot of fun to be with.
And we played a lot of tennis.
And then I met some of our professors that I played with.
And I was quite a good player.
So they liked to play with me.
And I had a real good group there.
We'd have a lot of beer and pizza parties.
And then we'd sit around the round table.
The real, the old, what do they call them, Greek symposium type thing where everybody can stand up and make their speeches.
Well, we took it literally, and we did it.
And we had a beer and pizza on a rainy day like this for hours.
And Sadat would pick up the bill, $20, whatever it was, and he'd pay.
So we'd all chip in.
I mean, you know, which was fun, if you can drink five or six hours of beer and pizza and talk your head off and anything under the sun.
So there was marvelous.
Thanks.
Oh, that's a good question.
See, these are the small details that I have.
Well, the German army will give books to their front line people.
Like, every night the canteen comes in, you can hear the pots.
In fact, they seem to be eating
the other side also, because there's very little firing during that time, during eating time.
During eating time?
Yeah.
No army wants to break up.
No, no.
Dinner.
And they sent out, they bring out books, and I remember it was a marvelous love story.
Yeah, sure.
It was a marvelous love story about a man, kind of a refugee of some sort, from the Russian army or something, that he was a fugitive.
And he had found some woman, a woman that took him on, that took him in, and it was a great love story.
And I always thought that, you know,
Yeah, it was my great love story, you see.
Oh, nice.
Yes, it is.
Yes, it is.
Yeah, it was a...
Yes, that's nice.
I felt it was, you know, uplifting.
The story was uplifting.
Yes, especially when you knew you were going to be taken prisoner by somebody in the next couple of days.
Yeah, and they have no idea where you're going to end up or what's going to happen to you.
That book has sustained me many, many times.
And I wish anybody could read it, like in any foxhole anywhere in the world.
which there are plenty of right now, this very minute, somebody's been shot at.
And you need an uplifting story.
How can I get out of this?
I'm going to find a woman that will put up with me after all this, you know, that type of thing.
So that was just a novel.
